channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.description: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Moderna says it plans to pull back on late-stage studies of some of its experimental vaccines.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.description: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass
item.description: The chairman, Casey Wasserman, has faced criticism ever since his name surfaced in the Epstein files. Mayor Karen Bass is the latest official to call on him to step down.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:description: Casey Wasserman, a powerful Los Angeles entertainment executive, has faced increasing calls from leaders in the city to resign as chairman of the 2028 Olympics organizing committee.

item.title: Tom Pritzker, Hyatt Heir, Steps Down as Executive Chairman Over Links to Epstein
item.description: The member of a prominent and wealthy family, Mr. Pritzker was in regular contact with the financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:description: In a letter sent to the Hyatt Hotels Corporation board on Monday, Thomas J. Pritzker said he had “exercised terrible judgment in maintaining contact” with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Columbia Punishes 2 Who Helped Epstein’s Girlfriend Enter Dental College
item.description: The release of documents tied to Jeffrey Epstein has sent ripples through the worlds of business, politics and academia, including at Columbia, where he helped his girlfriend gain entry.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.media:description: Columbia University said it will be donating money to nonprofits that work with survivors of sexual abuse after it disclosed that Jeffrey Epstein helped his girlfriend bypass admission standards.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Gear Up for Nuclear Talks Amid Rising Tensions
item.description: President Trump has called on Iran to reach an immediate accord or else face the threat of a possible U.S. attack.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, the Middle East envoy, and Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, in Davos, Switzerland, last month. They are expected to attend the negotiations with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: Memorials for Iran’s Slain Protesters Wil Test of State Crackdown
item.description: Ceremonies commemorating the 40 days after protesters were killed are planned this week, challenging the authorities’ ability to restrain them.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: Downtown Tehran this month. This week, families across Iran will commemorate the 40th-day memorials of thousands of Iranians killed Jan. 8-10.

item.title: Robert Duvall, ‘Godfather’ and ‘Apocalypse Now’ Actor, Dies at 95
item.description: An Oscar winner, he was known for disappearing into wide-ranging roles in movies like “Apocalypse Now” and “The Godfather” and in the television series “Lonesome Dove.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:description: In a long and varied career, Robert Duvall was nominated for seven Academy Awards for acting, and won once.

item.title: Where to Watch Robert Duvall’s Top Performances
item.description: He played rugged, capable men drawn from America’s past, present and possible future.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: In “The Godfather,” Robert Duvall played a lawyer advising a band of Italians who respect his counsel but don’t consider him a trusted insider.

item.title: Robert Duvall: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The actor, who had a knack for embodying a wealth of varied characters, had a sprawling and celebrated career.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Questions Swirl Around Russian Figure Skater in Her Olympic Debut
item.description: Adeliia Petrosian, 18, has the résumé of a medal contender — and ties to coaches and a skater who were at the center of a doping scandal at the last Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Adeliia Petrosian has skated outside Russia only once since 2022. She makes her Olympic debut on Tuesday at the Winter Games in Milan.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Hold New Round of Peace Talks, but Expectations Are Low
item.description: Both sides described previous U.S.-mediated negotiations as productive, although they did not appear to address sticking points like territory and security guarantees.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery brigade firing at Russian targets in the Zaporizhzhia region of eastern Ukraine in October.

item.title: Senators Meet Zelensky With Hopeful Message on Sanctions
item.description: During their visit, a pair of Democratic senators made the case for Congress to impose harsh penalties on Moscow for its continuing offensive.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:description: Senators Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island, left, and Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, center, visiting Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: In First Month as Governor, Abigail Spanberger Kicks Up Heat From the Right
item.description: The new governor of Virginia, who ran as a centrist Democrat and a former intelligence officer, says the attacks are a sign of her success.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller
item.media:description: Abigail Spanberger, governor of Virginia, in her office in the State Capitol this month.

item.title: Judge Orders Trump Administration to Restore Displays About Slavery at Washington’s House
item.description: The judge said the government did not have the power to erase or alter historical truths after the administration took down displays about slavery at the President’s House Site in Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: City officials sued the Interior Department after National Park Service workers took down the exhibits at the President’s House Site in Philadelphia last month.

item.title: How Much Will Trump’s Approval Rating Matter in the Midterms?
item.description: It’s not too early to consider the connection, and readers also have questions about the economy.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:description: Recent rallies in Minneapolis reflected growing dissatisfaction with the Trump administration.

item.title: 2 Killed in Shooting at High School Hockey Game in Rhode Island
item.description: The shooter was also dead, apparently by a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the authorities said. The shooting, which the police described as a “targeted event,” happened at the Dennis M. Lynch Arena in Pawtucket.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: State Police outside the Dennis M. Lynch Arena, an indoor ice skating rink, after a shooting in Pawtucket, R.I., on Monday.

item.title: Progress in Guthrie Case Is Fitful as Search Enters Its Third Week
item.description: Late-night bursts of activity have yielded few visible results as investigators hunt for Nancy Guthrie, the mother of a “Today” show host. The sheriff said Monday that her children and their spouses are not suspects.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hopes have soared with each apparent break, but Nancy Guthrie is still missing.

item.title: After Trip to Germany, AOC Expresses Frustrations
item.description: The congresswoman argued in an interview that presidential speculation, which included scrutiny of her slip-ups, had overshadowed her anti-authoritarian message at the Munich Security Conference.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez used her trip to Germany to argue that the best way to counteract far-right movements was to address people’s economic struggles.

item.title: Frederick Wiseman, 96, Penetrating Documentarian of Institutions, Dies
item.description: He exposed abuses in films like “Titicut Follies,” a once-banned portrait of a mental hospital, but ranged widely in subject matter, from a Queens neighborhood to a French restaurant.
item.dc:creator: John Anderson
item.media:description: Mr. Wiseman in an undated photo. “I don’t know if I can offer a general definition of what I’m doing,” he said in 2011, “except to say I’m trying to create dramatic structures out of ordinary experience.”

item.title: Frederick Wiseman Watched People Like Nobody Else
item.description: For more than 50 years, the influential documentarian found inspiration in filming the ways his ordinary subjects lived their lives.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:description: Frederick Wiseman’s direct cinema style and sharp observations made him a near-peerless documentary filmmaker.

item.title: Dinner Is Being Recorded, Whether You Know It or Not
item.description: As Meta smart glasses capture scenes in restaurants for social media, service workers and customers are becoming captive participants.
item.dc:creator: Luke Fortney
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dining rooms once plagued by camera flashes are now host to more discreet devices that can capture the meal: smart glasses.

item.title: Trump Risks Igniting a Nuclear Wildfire
item.description: The president’s approach to the rising nuclear danger is alarming.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times

item.title: What Does Body Positivity Mean in This New Weight Loss Era?
item.description: Can you love your body and still want to lose weight?
item.dc:creator: Gabriella Lascano and Amanda Su

item.title: Colbert Doesn’t Give an FCC About Calling Out CBS
item.description: “And because my network clearly doesn’t want us to talk about this, let’s talk about this,” Stephen Colbert said after CBS canceled a Texas congressman’s appearance on Monday’s “Late Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)
Real Time With Bill Maher (TV Program)

item.title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
item.description: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Adrienne Grunwald for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anderson Cooper has been a correspondent on the CBS newsmagazine for almost 20 years.

item.title: Teacher Killed in Crash After Man Fled in Car From ICE, Police Say
item.description: The man, who federal officials said had entered the United States illegally, was arrested and charged with first-degree homicide after the crash in Savannah, Ga., according to the county police.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

item.title: Dana Eden, Co-Creator of ‘Tehran,’ Dies During Filming of Fourth Season
item.description: Ms. Eden, 52, who was also an executive producer of the Emmy-winning show, was found in a hotel room in Athens. Greek police said they did not suspect foul play.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Dana Eden at the premier of Season 2 of “Tehran” in New York in 2022.

item.title: Winter Storms Could Bring 8 Feet of Snow to Parts of California
item.description: The greatest impact is expected across Northern California, where a pair of powerful storms began on Sunday night and were forecast to last into the week.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Livia Albeck-Ripka
